problem: If the roots of the quadratic equation $\frac32x^2+11x+c=0$ are $x=\frac{-11\pm\sqrt{7}}{3}$, then what is the value of $c$?
solution: By the quadratic formula, the roots of the equation are $$x=\frac{-(11)\pm\sqrt{(11)^2-4(\frac32)c}}{2(\frac32)},$$which simplifies to $$x=\frac{-11\pm\sqrt{121-6c}}{3}.$$This looks exactly like our target, except that we have to get the $121-6c$ under the square root to equal $7$. So, we solve the equation $121-6c=7$, which yields $c=\boxed{19}$.
chatgpt_solution:
By the quadratic formula, the roots are $$x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}=\frac{-11\pm\sqrt{121-18c}}3.$$So equating denominators to $3$ and multiplying both sides of the equation by $3$ gives \begin{align*}
-11\pm\sqrt{7}&=\sqrt{121-18c}\\
\sqrt{7}&=\sqrt{121-18c}+11\\
0&=\sqrt{121-18c}-\sqrt{7}-11,
\end{align*}from which it follows that $\sqrt{121-18c}-\sqrt{7}-11=0$. Notice that if $\sqrt{121-18c}-\sqrt{7}-11=0$, then $\sqrt{121-18c}=\sqrt{7}+11$. Squaring both sides gives $$121-18c=7+22\sqrt{7}+121,$$which then gives $18c=22\sqrt{7}\, \Rightarrow \, c = \boxed{\frac{11\sqrt7}7}.$
